Any idea why 2d is that much slower than 1d?
Maybe add Storage::get_mutex(device_mask) to the global storage object and reference it from all managers.

The issue here would be that some managers do not have any mutex (like the cpu_device_storage) and they should not have them. So the get_mutex(cpu) would be a little confusing (since it would not actually be used by anything). But if that is fine, then I will make that change.

For GPU 1/2-D kernels, one possible reason might be this line and the following "atomicAdd" function call.
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/5519/files#diff-b6c5be2d23abce9c69031e26504e7c4fR387

The "if" condition would cause thread divergence in the 2D cases and consequently, more runtime than 1D.

The unpool_sum has no such condition check for 2/3 d kernels, and the relative difference between 1D and 2D is not that big.

But if we could have a mask as an invisible output, the unpool_max should be faster and have no atomicAdd calls.

On top of the shaping issue, the other issue is it's not entirely clear what the gradient for a dynamic k would be (or what would make one useful). I would recommend the following architecture, or something like it, to instead get the effect you want. It has the nice property that the function has a bit of burliness around the edges which lets the gradients "see" whether it's useful to expand or contract k.

First, for your topk function, set its k to always be the maximum selection size you're willing to allow (we'll "softly" select a smaller k next)

Next you want to gate the values of the selected k, which means we want to multiply it by a vector with values between 0 and 1 so that only some of the values get "let through." Furthermore, the gate vector should have a monotonically decreasing property as you go further down the k elements and we want it fairly sharp so most elements are near the value 1 or 0. We want this because if the bottom k - k2 gate values are effectively zero and the top k2 gate values are effectively one, then you have an effective dynamic top k2 parameter.

So the question is how do you generate such a gate vector that is differentiable on some parameter that affects k2? Here is one way.

-Create a constant inds, which is a vector with the value [0, 1, 2, ... k-1] (e.g., what an arange function would produce).

-Create a scalar variable k_alt and broadcast it to size k.

-Create a constant "sharpness" weight, w (choose its value as you desire)

-Set your gate vector to the be the result of sigmoid(w * (k_alt - inds))

The output of that sigmoid will produce a monotonically decreasing vector from 1 to 0. Increasing w will push most of the values near 1 or 0 with the transition from 1 to zero happening over few indices. decreasing w will "smear" the values a bit more and cause the transition from near 1 to near zero happen over more indices. 

Importantly, as the continuous k_alt parameter is increased, more of the k instances pass through the gate (more values near 1) and as k_alt decreases, fewer of the k instances pass through the gate (more values near zero).

```
major_axis = [DataDesc.get_batch_axis(x.layout) for x in data_shapes]
```

_ means protected function. pack/unpack are public

Yeah, underscore prefix usually marks "internal use" properties or methods. So do we expect users to explicitly call pack_weights, or do we expect solely the "checkpoint" methods to call those. For the former, I'd recommend that we document all public APIs, while in later case we should add the underscore to make it clear it's not for regular users.

BTW: The deconvolution implemented is actually a transposed convolution. Tensorflow has renamed it to conv2d_transpose. Should we take the chance to make the name correct?
Refs:
https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/256#issuecomment-162257789
https://github.com/vdumoulin/conv_arithmetic

@eric-haibin-lin Maybe not very exactly. Problem of the  varied shape inference using mxnet is not  unncessary optimzation, but some repeated passes. For fully cnn, since the symbol will not change, it doesn't need to get a new indexed graph for each batch. Not only the memory pool, many other members of graph executor can also  be shared in the case of varied shape inference.  Creating  a new excutor for each batch is not very efficient in this case.
cool, glad to hear that.

You can move epoch end callback to after eval_data then do something like this:
metric = ...
val_metric = ...
def callback(...):
    metric.get()
    val_metrci.get()

module.fit(metric, val_metric, epoch end callback=callback)

The problem is that current bucket module needs to rebind executor if the batch's bucket key is not presented in bucket-key list, even though the symbol keeps the same. And this process can be further optimized by sharing more stuffs. Is this accurate?

MXNET have to synchronize between two machine(default seem to be 9092 port)， so if the firewall is on, the program will run on the workers but can't communicate with each other, it looks like blocked. I am not sure this is your problem.

After adapting the submodules - extra ssd operator moved to contrib
Apparently ./model/ssd_300-symbol.json needs to be updated.
"op": "MultiBoxPrior" or "MultiBoxTarget" need to be update to 
` "op": "_contrib_MultiBoxPrior" `
and 
`"op": "_contrib_MultiBoxTarget"`

I think
```
fc = mx.FullyConnected(num_hidden=5)
sm = mx.SoftmaxOutput(fc)
```
means multi-class (not multi-label) classification.

MXNet supports multi-output but it might be inefficient in multi-class classification.
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/910

The following is instrumental.
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/647
